pullRequest.body:
This PR creates the file `CategoryTheory.Sites.LocallyInjective` which develops the basic API of locally injective morphisms of presheaves. The file `CategoryTheory.Sites.Surjective` is renamed `CategoryTheory.Sites.LocallySurjective` and shall be expanded in a future PR.

Co-authored-by: Andrew Yang


---

- [x] depends on: #12332


<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

**[imports]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion ```
Is it possible to use `[ConcreteCategory E] [HasSheafify J E] [HasSheafCompose J (forget E)]` instead?
Unfortunately, I do not know how to prove that the map to the associated sheaf is locally injective without using its explicit description (which I am doing in two steps using the plus construction).

I thought those conditions guarantee that `forget E` preserves sheafification, but maybe a new class
```lean
class PreservesSheafification {D E} [Category D] [Category E]
    [HasWeakSheafify J D] [HasWeakSheafify J E] (F : D ⥤ E) where
  iso : ∀ P : Cᵒᵖ ⥤ D, sheafify J P ⋙ F ≅ sheafify J (P ⋙ F)
  prop : ∀ P : Cᵒᵖ ⥤ D, whiskerRight (toSheafify J P) F ≫ (iso P).hom = toSheafify J (P ⋙ F)
```
is needed here.
I think the main purpose of these abstract classes is to hide the plus plus construction as an implementation detail and I think we should discourage the use of the latter outside of the construction files if possible.
 
This can come in a later PR though.
I have started PR #12332 (where I define `PreservesSheafification`, but as a Prop), but it remains to show that the forget functor satisfies this condition...

Actually, what would be also useful (after developing a little bit more locally surjective/injective maps), is to introduce a type-class saying that a morphism of presheaves (in a concrete category) is in `J.W` (i.e. iso after sheafification) iff it is both locally injective and locally surjective. At some point, we have to show that under certain circumstances, this holds, and the code in this PR shall help doing that. (In the future, I plan to allow sharper universe bounds using certain PR on 1-hypercovers, like #13012.)

This section can be replaced by 
(`infer_instance` is able to prove the old `isLocallyInjective_toSheafify'` from the new one)
```
variable (P : Cᵒᵖ ⥤ Type max u v)

open GrothendieckTopology Plus

instance isLocallyInjective_toPlus : IsLocallyInjective J (J.toPlus P) where
  equalizerSieve_mem {X} x y h := by
    erw [toPlus_eq_mk, toPlus_eq_mk, eq_mk_iff_exists] at h
    obtain ⟨W, h₁, h₂, eq⟩ := h
    exact J.superset_covering (fun Y f hf => congr_fun (congr_arg Subtype.val eq) ⟨Y, f, hf⟩) W.2

instance isLocallyInjective_toSheafify : IsLocallyInjective J (J.toSheafify P) := by
  dsimp [GrothendieckTopology.toSheafify]
  rw [GrothendieckTopology.plusMap_toPlus]
  infer_instance

instance isLocallyInjective_toSheafify' [ConcreteCategory.{max u v} D]
    (P : Cᵒᵖ ⥤ D) [HasWeakSheafify J D] [J.HasSheafCompose (forget D)]
    [J.PreservesSheafification (forget D)] :
    IsLocallyInjective J (toSheafify J P) := by
  rw [← isLocallyInjective_forget_iff, ← sheafComposeIso_hom_fac,
    ← toSheafify_plusPlusIsoSheafify_hom]
  infer_instance

end
```
Thanks for this code!
Shouldn't this be defined similarly as `CategoryTheory.Presheaf.IsSheaf` for arbitrary categories and then show that they are equivalent for concrete categories?

I had considered doing so. It could express that the restriction maps given by a covering sieve are monomorphic families. I think there would be little use for this notion, and I do not know how to relate this categorical notion and the concrete one. (If it were only about a single monomorphism, it would suffice to assume that the forget functor preserves mono (or finite limits), but in general, as we do not have reasonable bounds about the cardinality/universe of covering families, I do not think it is worth introducing this notion.)
I see. How about `Presieve.IsSeparated J (P ⋙ forget A)` then?
Thanks for the suggestion!
Maybe you can extract out the fact that `IsLocallyInjective J φ` iff `equalizerSieve (φ.app X x) (φ.app X y) ∈ J X.unop` implies `equalizerSieve x y ∈ J X.unop` from this proof?
Thanks very much for this suggestion! This is now `isLocallyInjective_iff_equalizerSieve_mem_imp`.
Can this be made into an iff?
Yes, I have added this lemma.

```suggestion
    equalizerSieve x y ∈ J X.unop :=
```
This can be an iff too if you so desire.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: morphisms of presheaves that are locally injective for a Grothendieck topology
